content.content: Vena Cava: the largest vein in the body that returns unoxygenated blood back from the capillaries to the right atrium.
Aorta: the largest artery in the body that exits the left ventricle and carries oxygenated blood to the capillaries.
Capillaries: A braided system of microscopic vessels (arterioles and venules) where perfusion occurs.
Perfusion = exchange of O₂ for CO₂ at the cellular level.
* The left ventricle is the strongest compartment of the heart, and is more prone to infarction.
Understand the general concept of the cardiopulmonary system.

items: 1. The components of blood and their function (WBCs, hemoglobin as part of the RBC, platelets, plasma).
2. The job of RBCs as the vehicle for oxygen transport.
3. Perfusion as the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide at the cellular level via the capillary beds.
4. The flow and direction of the circulatory system, as well as the major names of its components labeled in the cardiopulmonary diagram.
Teach the cardiopulmonary system to another person in class.

content.content: Know how to identify the bones within the Skeletal System.

items: 1. Locate and name the major bones of the skeletal system and professionally relay the information in a patient report.
Name the bone that is splinted.
Use correct bone names when calling in a patient report.
